starfleet_message: Captain’s Log, Stardate 47826.4 — Long-range sensors have detected anomalous warp-harmonic emissions from Velis II, a Class-M world with early fusion-age technology and established orbital platforms. Scans indicate the source is a contained power core now installed in a secured research facility on the northern continent. Analysis shows the device is Romulan in origin — likely wreckage from a scout that crashed twenty-five years ago and was later recovered by surface teams. Velisian engineers have disassembled and reassembled the core into a planetary energy lattice. Their adaptations are unstable; continued operation threatens a catastrophic containment failure capable of destabilizing the atmosphere.
mission_description: Locate the Velisian research complex housing the Romulan core, assess the containment risk, and neutralize the device discreetly—preserving life on Velis II while ensuring the Velisians never know of off-world intervention.

dialogue_tree.line: Captain, the emissions are coming from a high-security complex—heavy shielding markers, dedicated orbital tugs. They’ve clearly recovered and relocated the device.

options.label: Data, verify origin and current configuration.
options.crew_reply: Data: Confirmed. The matrix is Romulan; containment field harmonics match a mid-24th century singularity drive. The Velisians have incorporated the core into a distributed grid feeding their northern megacity.

options.label: La Forge, how unstable is it?
options.crew_reply: La Forge: Containment oscillations are growing. If they continue to ramp it, they’ll trigger a phase cascade—atmospheric ionization, global weather collapse.

options.label: Worf, any signs of a third party?
options.crew_reply: Worf: Negative, Captain. No off-world signatures detected. This is a local operation.

dialogue_tree.line: There is exhilaration in their scientists and fear in their leaders. The facility’s staff believe they have solved an energy crisis; some factions wish to weaponize the core.

options.label: Options, Number One?
options.crew_reply: Riker: A covert beam-out. Recover the core before they can use it further.

options.label: La Forge, alternatives from orbit?
options.crew_reply: La Forge: I can deliver a gravimetric inversion from the deflector to collapse the singularity safely, but it will cut power across the continent and be visible.

options.label: Crusher, worst-case casualties?
options.crew_reply: Crusher: If it breaches, immediate fatalities could number in the tens of millions with long-term atmospheric poisoning.

dialogue_tree.line: The Prime Directive forbids cultural contamination—but their use of alien technology places this catastrophe squarely in our hands to mitigate. We will act, and we will not reveal ourselves.

options.label: Mask the gravimetric pulse beneath natural solar interference. Execute at maximum precision.
options.crew_reply: La Forge: Understood. Routing the pulse through the sun’s limb to diffuse our signature.

options.label: Riker, prepare a non-intrusive surveillance footprint. No rescue, no contact.
options.crew_reply: Riker: Aye, Captain. We’ll be ghosts.

options.label: Keep weapons cold. This is not a battle; it’s a rescue in silence.

dialogue_tree.line: Pulse initialized. The core collapsed inward. The facility’s reactors tripped—continent-wide blackouts—but the cascade halted. No large-scale detonation registered.

options.label: Casualty and environmental status?
options.crew_reply: Data: Preliminary: localized failures, infrastructure damage, but no catastrophic atmospheric ionization. Population impact limited and recoverable.

options.label: Did they observe an external craft or anomalous signature?
options.crew_reply: Worf: Negative. Public broadcasts label the event ‘The Silence of the Sky’—an omen or miracle, depending on the speaker.

options.label: Seal the telemetry. Encrypt and classify at the highest level.

dialogue_tree.line: Their leaders are already shaping the story. Some call it divine protection; others, a warning from the heavens. You’ve spared them—but you’ve also set their mythology in motion.

options.label: Then let their stories serve as lessons. The truth can wait until they’re ready to understand it.
options.crew_reply: Troi: And when that day comes, they’ll wonder who listened to their silence.

options.label: That, Counselor, is how history begins—quietly.
options.crew_reply: Troi: Perhaps silence is the truest beginning, Captain.

options.label: No further action required. Helm, set course away from Velis II, one-quarter impulse.
options.crew_reply: Riker: Aye, sir. Course laid in. Leaving them to their miracle.

reflection.line: They’ll never know how close they came to destruction, Captain.
Let that ignorance be their salvation, Counselor. Some lessons are best left untaught.

debriefs.text: The Enterprise neutralized the Romulan singularity core housed in the Velisian research complex without detection. Atmospheric destabilization was prevented; critical infrastructure was disabled but recoverable. Velis II remains unaware of extraterrestrial intervention.

Starfleet Command classed the operation as an emergency exception; the crew received quiet commendations and a sealed report to Intelligence. No Romulan authorities were alerted; the incident did not provoke interstellar diplomatic consequences.
Velis II will rebuild under the myth of the ‘Silence of the Sky.’ Starfleet considers the outcome the least disruptive possible end to a potential extinction event.

The gravimetric inversion misfired; the singularity breached and produced a hemispheric plasma surge. Casualties numbered in the tens of millions, and the northern continent suffered long-term ecological collapse.
The Velisians detected anomalous signatures and began covertly investigating; the risk of exposure and political fallout increased dramatically.
Starfleet launched an inquiry into the decision to act; the crew’s conduct was subject to review, with the Prime Directive at the heart of the debate.
